title: When bipartisan lawmakers broke into song, Sept. 11, 2001
text:
From front left: Tom Daschle, Trent Lott, Dennis Hastert, David Bonior and Richard Gephardt lead a prayer on Sept. 11 on the steps of the Capitol. When bipartisan lawmakers broke into song, Sept. 11, 2001

As the sun set on this day in 2001, dozens of Republican and Democratic members of Congress stood on the East Front of the U.S. Capitol in a twilight tableau aimed at calming a society shaken by the biggest single terrorist attack on U.S. soil in the nation’s history. Many hugged one other as they spontaneously burst into a rendition of “God Bless America.”

With President George W. Bush away for much of the day, the lawmakers became the nation’s main public presence. They called the terrorist strikes on the World Trade Center in New York and the Pentagon near Washington acts of war and vowed that Americans would stand united and fight back.

Story Continued Below

As flags at the Capitol hung at half-staff to mourn the nearly 3,000 people who died in the coordinated attacks, congressional leaders announced that the lawmakers would go back to work the first thing on Sept. 12 to persevere despite the loss of life.

Sen. Hillary Clinton (D-N.Y.), a future two-time presidential candidate, wept. She was one of the dozens of shaken legislators who in the afternoon had gone to the headquarters of the U.S. Capitol Police, for a telephone briefing by congressional leaders, who had been evacuated earlier in the day.

“Senators and House members, Democrats and Republicans, will stand shoulder to shoulder to fight this evil that’s been perpetrated on this nation,” said House Speaker Dennis Hastert (R-Ill.). “We will stand together to make sure that those who brought forth this evil deed will pay a price.”

Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle (D-S.D.) called the attacks “an assault on our people and on our freedom.” Daschle added: “As the representatives of the people, we are here to declare that our resolve has not been weakened by these horrific and cowardly acts.”

Thousands were at work on Capitol Hill on a sun-splashed Tuesday morning. Visitors lined up for guided tours. The architect of the Capitol was preparing for an unveiling of plans for the new Capitol Visitor Center. First lady Laura Bush was at the Russell Senate Office Building, preparing to testify before the Senate Education Committee.

When one of the planes — the fourth jet to have been hijacked — crashed in Western Pennsylvania, United Flight 93 was 20 minutes flying time from the nation's capital.

In its report, the 9/11 commission wrote that “it appears as though the White House was the primary target for the … plane and the U.S. Capitol the alternate.” It further stated that the [terrorist] pilot’s [suicidal] “objective was to crash his airliner into symbols of the American Republic, the Capitol or the White House. He was defeated by the alerted, unarmed passengers of United 93.”

The commission concluded: “The nation owes an eternal debt of gratitude to those who took action to ensure that Flight 93 never reached its target.”

SOURCE: WWW.NYTIMES.COM; 9/11 COMMISSION REPORT
description: In a day of shock and terror, they offered  a rendition of 'God Bless America.'
